STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 19, 2024
Jeana Koerber
GREAT LAKES CENTER FOR AUTISM TREATMENT & RES
9616 PORTAGE RD,
PORTAGE, MI, 49002-7257
Re: License #: CI390318114
Investigation #: 2024SIC0001217
Dear Ms. Koerber:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis
Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024SIC0001217
Special Investigation Intake Date: March 4, 2024
License #: CI390318114
Licensee Group Organization: Residential Opportunities, Inc.
Licensee Designee: Rebecca Lopez
Chief Administrator: Jeana Koerber
Agency Name: GREAT LAKES CENTER FOR AUTISM
TREATMENT & RES
Agency Address: 9616 PORTAGE RD
PORTAGE, MI 49002-7257
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 02/11/2025
Capacity: 12
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
3/4/2024 4:30 PM Phone Special Investigation Initiation; Interview
3/5/2024 11:25 AM Face to Face Documentation received or sent;
Unannounced Visit; Interview
3/7/2024 12:12 PM Face to Face Interview
3/7/2024 8:03 PM Email Other
3/12/2024 8:55 AM Email Documentation received or sent
3/12/2024 1:16 PM Email Documentation received or sent
3/12/2024 3:10 PM Phone Interview
3/15/2024 2:45 PM Face to Face Interview
3/15/2024 3:31 PM Email Documentation received or sent
4/10/2024 4:00 PM Phone Interview
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4129 Institutions serving developmentally
Section disabled youth; written procedures.
Description (1) An institution providing care to developmentally disabled
residents shall require staff to follow written procedures for
bathing, feeding, toilet training, and daily activities of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff won't check a youth’s brief before they go to bed. Staff has
said to just let the overnight staff worry about it. This has
happened on several occasions.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 3/4/24.
Complainant reported she received the complaint from an
anonymous source and did not have any contact information for
the person who made the complaint. Complainant reported there
were no youth or staff names associated to this allegation. Since
the original complaint source was anonymous and no contact
information was provided, no further details could be requested.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 3/5/24 and via phone on 4/10/24. CA reported it is
obvious when a youth has soiled their briefs, and she hasn’t heard
about or received complaints about any staff neglecting to change
a youth’s briefs before they go to bed. CA reported Youth A was at
the facility until 1/23/24 and he wore briefs all day/night. CA
reported Youth B only wears briefs at night. CA reported Youth C
and Youth D wear briefs all day/night. CA reported because the
youth are teenagers, it is not appropriate for staff members to be
randomly checking youth’s briefs as a standard practice. However,
each youth in briefs has an Activities of Daily Living (ADL) plan
and/or a bathroom protocol. Part of each youth’s ADL is to take
them to the bathroom before bed, and it is expected staff would
change a youth’s brief at that time. CA reported all staff receive
on-going training and feedback about bathroom protocols and
ADLs from BCBA (Board-Certified Behavior Analyst) staff during
frequent observations of staff & youth interactions and data
collection throughout their employment.
Staff 1, Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 6, Staff 8, Staff 9, Staff 10, Staff
11, Staff 12, and Program Manager were all interviewed face
to face separately at the facility on 3/7/24. Staff 13 was
interviewed via phone on 3/12/24. All staff reported they haven’t
heard about or witnessed any staff neglecting any youths’
2

bathroom needs or neglecting to change their briefs and leaving it
for the next shift.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24.
Staff 2 reported she has never heard about or witnessed any staff
neglecting any youths’ bathroom needs or neglecting to change
their briefs and leaving it for the next shift. Staff 2 reported if a
youth soils at the time of shift change, it might be left for third shift
to take care of due to the natural transitions of staff, but not as an
intentional act. Staff 2 could not provide any examples of youth or
staff who might have been involved in a situation like she
described.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24.
Staff 3 reported she has never heard about or witnessed any staff
neglecting any youths’ bathroom needs or neglecting to change
their briefs and leaving it for the next shift. Staff 3 reported the
only time she can see something like that occurring is if Youth C is
escalated. Staff 3 reported when Youth C has behaviors, he
refuses to allow staff to check his brief, refuses to go to the
bathroom when he’s soiled, etc. Staff 3 reported since staff are not
allowed to physically take him to the bathroom, they are required
to wait it out until he complies, which may naturally go from
second to third shift if his behaviors last for a while.
Staff 7 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24.
Staff 7 reported she has never heard about or witnessed any staff
neglecting any youths’ bathroom needs or neglecting to change
their briefs and leaving it for the next shift. Staff 7 reported there
are times Youth B goes to sleep early, so his brief might not get
checked one more time before he goes to sleep, and they don’t
wake him up after he’s already sleeping. Staff 7 reported this isn’t
a normal occurrence or something that’s done intentionally.
Staff 14 was interviewed face to face at another facility on
3/15/24. Staff 14 reported there was one instance months ago
where she asked Staff 6 if he was going to change a youth’s brief
because the youth might be wet, and Staff 6 said “Nah, third shift
can deal with it”. Staff 14 reported she cannot remember which
youth it was, who else was working, or when it occurred. Staff 14
stated she never reported it as a concern, and it hasn’t been a
pattern of behavior she’s noticed.
Youth A, Youth B, Youth D were unable to be interviewed
because they are non-verbal.
3

Youth C was interviewed via phone on 4/17/24. Youth C reported
staff help him go to the bathroom and change his clothes and/or
brief when needed. Youth C would not or could not answer any
other questions due to his limited skills because of his diagnosis.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• ADL (Activities of Daily Living) Policy states these plans
include information on a youth’s bathing, toileting, feeding,
and other individually identified needs. Assistance will be
provided by support and assessment, training, and/or
ongoing support. Staff are to follow the steps as described
in the plan.
• Youth A’s Bathroom Protocol dated 8/9/23 states Youth A
should be using the bathroom once every hour during
waking hours and staff should record bathroom trips on
daily data sheets.
• Youth A’s January 2024 (Youth A moved from the facility
on 1/23/24) daily logs do not reflect any concerns about
staff not changing youth’s brief throughout the day as
required.
• Youth B’s Bathroom Protocol dated 9/1/23 states Youth B
should be using the bathroom once every 1.5 hours during
waking hours to gain independence with toileting.
• Youth B does not have daily logs reflecting bathroom trips
because he does not wear briefs during the day.
• Youth C’s Bathroom Protocol dated 2/14/24 states Youth C
should be using the bathroom once every hour during
waking hours and staff should record bathroom trips on
daily data sheets.
• Youth C’s January and February 2024 daily logs do not
reflect any concerns about staff not changing youth’s brief
throughout the day as required.
• Youth D’s Bathroom Protocol dated 2/13/23 states staff
should place any soiled clothing items in a nearby laundry
hamper to be washed. Youth D should be using the
bathroom once every 1.5 hours during waking hours. If
Youth D independently asks to use the bathroom, staff will
immediately stop the current activity/demand and take him
4

to the bathroom. Enter information on the interval data
sheet.
• Youth D’s January and February 2024 daily logs do not
reflect any concerns about staff not changing youth’s brief
throughout the day as required.
• Staff 6 has five disciplinary actions in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 6 received training on
the ADL policy during new hire orientation on 2/6/23,
2/20/23 and 2/23/24. He also received more specific hands-
on training for ADLs during shadow and training shifts on
2/28/23, 3/1/23, 3/7/23, 3/9/23 and 3/14/23.
• Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 7, Staff 8, Staff
9, Staff 10, Staff 11, Staff 12, Staff 13, Staff 14, and Staff
15 received training on the ADL policy during their new
employee orientations and more specific hands-on training
for ADLs during shadow and training shifts. All these dates
were provided for each staff listed.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. There is no evidence to support any
staff failed to check any youth’s briefs before bed or left a youth’s
bathroom needs for another shift to handle. The one concern Staff
14 mentioned about Staff 6 is not documented anywhere, Staff 14
did not report it, the youth is unknown, and the exact timeframe is
unknown.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff used blocking pads to push a youth into their room.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 3/4/24.
Complainant reported she received the complaint from an
anonymous source and did not have any contact information for
the person who made the complaint. Complainant reported this
allegation was specific to Youth A, but there were no staff names
5

provided with the allegation. Since the original complaint source
was anonymous and no contact information was provided, no
further details could be requested.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 3/5/24 and via phone on 4/10/24. CA reported
blocking pads would be used if a youth was being aggressive
towards staff but shouldn’t ever be utilized to push a youth. CA
reported she has never seen or heard of any staff members
utilizing blocking pads to push Youth A into his room. CA reported
all staff receive on-going training and feedback about Behavior
Support Plans (BSPs) from BCBA staff during frequent
observations of staff & youth interactions and data collection
throughout their employment.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 3/7/24. PM reported he has never heard of or seen any
staff utilize blocking pads to push Youth A into his room. PM
reported he reviews all incident reports and hasn’t seen anything
like that mentioned on those reports either.
Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 4, Staff 6, Staff 7, Staff 8, Staff 9, Staff 10,
and Staff 11 were all interviewed face to face separately at the
facility on 3/7/24. Staff 13 was interviewed via phone on
3/12/24. All staff reported they have never heard of or seen any
staff utilize blocking pads to push Youth A into his room.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24
and Staff 14 was interviewed face to face at a different facility
on 3/15/24. Both staff reported they have never heard of or seen
any staff utilize blocking pads to push Youth A into his room. Both
staff reported Youth A prefers to be in his room, and it is very
unlikely anyone would ever have to use force to get him to go into
his room.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24.
Staff 5 reported he has never heard of or seen any staff utilize
blocking pads to push Youth A into his room. Staff 5 reported
using blocking pads to push a youth is strictly against the facility’s
restraint model and specifically a technique they’re trained not to
use. Staff 5 reported if something like that happened, it would be a
recipient’s rights complaint, and had he heard of/seen it, he would
have made the complaint himself.
Youth A was unable to be interviewed because he is non-
verbal.
6

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Blocking Pad Procedures outlines when and how to utilize
blocking pads at the facility. It outlines what are appropriate
techniques when using the blocking pads. It says pushing,
striking, or shoving of someone with the pad is not allowed.
• Great Lakes Center for Autism Treatment and Researched
Licensed Settings Policy Regarding Discipline and
Behavior Management states pushing a youth on any part
of their body is prohibited.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. All employees interviewed reported
they have never seen or heard of any staff using a blocking pad to
push Youth A into his room.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation One youth is fearful of staff, and this same staff ignores Behavior
Support Plans (BSP).
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 3/4/24.
Complainant reported she received the complaint from an
anonymous source and did not have any contact information for
the person who made the complaint. Complainant reported this
allegation only provided a last name for a youth, but not the first
name. Complainant reported there were no staff names provided
with the allegation. Since the original complaint source was
anonymous and no contact information was provided, no further
details could be requested.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 3/5/24. CA reported Youth B’s last name matches the
Complainant’s information. CA reported Youth B has Angelman’s
Syndrome, which means he is easy to excite and reacts better to
very happy and animated people. CA reported if he doesn’t like a
staff, it is very difficult for staff to regain rapport with him. CA
reported Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 6, Staff 9, Staff 13, and Staff 15
7

have all struggled in their interactions with Youth B. CA reported
they all have more of a flat affect or haven’t mastered a poker face
and show more annoyance, which Youth B doesn’t react well to.
CA reported although he doesn’t prefer them, none of them run
his any better or worse than anyone else and he doesn’t express
or demonstrate fear towards any of them. CA reported there have
been no complaints about any staff intentionally or blatantly
ignoring Youth B’s BSP. CA reported there have been no
complaints about Youth B demonstrating or expressing fear
towards any staff.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 3/7/24. PM reported it is hard to discern fear for Youth
B due to his diagnosis of Angelman’s Syndrome, which means he
almost always has a happy affect. PM reported there’s an ebb and
flow for staff he likes and doesn’t like, but no staff stand out as a
consistent issue for him. PM reported he hasn’t seen Youth B
demonstrate or express anything towards any staff he would
consider as fear. PM reported he reviews all incident reports for
the facility and can’t think of any situations where there have been
reports or complaints of any staff intentionally ignoring Youth B’s
BSP. PM reported there are various staff who will make honest
mistakes and might be provided feedback, but nothing significant.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24.
Staff 1 reported Youth B has never cowered, run away from, or
demonstrated any fear towards any staff. Staff 1 reported there
are times in Youth B’s BSP, staff are instructed to ignore certain
behaviors, but he has never seen any staff willfully ignore Youth
B’s BSP. Staff 1 reported if he saw or heard something like that,
he would correct the behavior.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24.
Staff 2 reported Youth B has never expressed or demonstrated
any fear towards any staff. Staff 2 reported due to his diagnosis,
Youth B is one who you would be able to determine very easily if
he was fearful because he is open with his emotions and whether
he likes/dislikes something or someone. Staff 2 reported she has
never seen or heard of any staff intentionally ignoring Youth B’s
BSP. Staff 2 reported there are times outlined in Youth B’s BSP
when staff are instructed to ignore him/his behaviors when his
wristband is flipped to orange. Staff 2 reported there are times
staff forget to check his wristband and will engage with him when
they’re not supposed to, but it is random occurrences with various
staff, and are honest mistakes rather than willfully trying to negate
his BSP.
8

Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24.
Staff 3 reported she has not heard or seen Youth B demonstrate
or express any fear towards any staff. Staff 3 reported Youth B is
very dramatic and expressive in his body language, so someone
who doesn’t know him well might think that translates into fear, but
it might just be the way he’s expressing a need or dislike. Staff 3
reported part of her job is treatment integrity, providing feedback
to staff, modeling appropriate reactions, and demonstrating what a
youth’s treatment plan/BSP should look like. Staff 3 reported
Youth B has an attention-maintained function, so it's difficult to
discern if he doesn’t like a staff, is fearful of a staff, or doesn’t
want to listen to a staff. Staff 3 reported Youth B has some
preferred staff, and it is very evident which staff he doesn’t prefer
to be around. The staff Youth B doesn’t prefer are Staff 4, Staff 5,
Staff 6, Staff 9, and Staff 13. Staff 3 reported all these staff
struggle in their interactions with him because they have a difficult
time implementing his BSP. Staff 3 reported Youth B’s BSP
requires a lot of “wait” strategies (i.e. waiting for him to be
appropriate or improve behaviors), which can be difficult for some
staff to be patient and wait it out. Staff 3 reported she has given all
these staff feedback multiple times, and other employees have
had to provide them feedback as well. Staff 3 reported Youth B
requires a lot of attention, social reinforcement and excitement
from staff based on his diagnosis. If he’s doing a great job, a staff
must almost throw a party for him, be very joyous and be a hype
person, which these identified staff struggle doing. Staff 3 reported
she doesn’t believe these staff are intentionally trying to violate
Youth B’s BSP, but they struggle with implementation consistently
due to all the required components.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24.
Staff 4 reported he has not seen Youth B demonstrate or express
any fear towards any staff, but he does express when he has
preferred staff. Staff 4 reported Youth B makes it clear when he
doesn’t like a staff. Staff 4 reported Youth B doesn’t like him when
he gives Youth B his medications or when he helps Youth B with
transitions. Staff 4 reported even if another staff gives Youth B his
medications or a prompt, Youth B might still get upset and take it
out on Staff 4 if he is present. Staff 4 reported Youth B’s BSP has
a 2-minute wait strategy after prompts are provided. Staff 4
reported there are frequent times when Youth B yells at him, hits
him, knocks medications out of his hand, or throws a tablet at him
when Staff 4 is waiting for Youth B to comply with a prompt. Staff
4 reported when Youth B has those behaviors, Staff 4 will ask
another staff to come in and take over, while Staff 4 provides
9

back-up, if needed. Staff 4 reported there are other times when
Youth B enters a room, sees Staff 4 and expresses he is happy to
see him by smiling at him and hugging him. Staff 4 reported he
has been working on developing a better relationship with Youth B
over the last 9 months, and they have made a lot of progress.
Staff 4 reported Youth B is one of the harder youths because he’s
attention-seeking. Staff 4 reported when Youth B’s wristband is
flipped to orange, it means a staff is supposed to ignore Youth B
due to his behaviors. Staff 4 reported there are times when he will
enter a room and not notice the orange wristband, and Youth B
will react even more positively to Staff 4, so Staff 4 takes
advantage of the moments to build a positive relationship with
Youth B. Staff 4 reported he doesn’t intentionally ignore the
wristband or Youth B’s BSP but makes an honest mistake and
forgets to check.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/7/24.
Staff 5 reported he has not seen Youth B demonstrate or express
any fear towards any staff, but he does express when he has
preferred staff. Staff 5 reported Youth B normally doesn’t like him
and expresses his dislike by swatting at Staff 5, gesturing for Staff
5 to go away, flinching when Staff 5 comes near him, or crying
when Staff 5 goes near Youth B. Staff 5 reported Youth B requires
high energy and excitement from staff due to his diagnosis, and
Staff 5 doesn’t provide that high excitement because it’s not his
normal personality/demeanor. Staff 5 reported there are staff who
don’t always follow Youth B’s BSP either because they’re not
informed, they’re apathetic, they take the path of least resistance,
or they’re burned out. Staff 5 reported he feels he gets in trouble
when he doesn’t follow a BSP but doesn’t feel others get in trouble
as often. Staff 5 was unwilling to provide any names of staff or
specific examples but reported they’re mostly on first shift.
Staff 6, Staff 7, Staff 8, Staff 9, Staff 10, Staff 11, and Staff 12
were interviewed face to face separately at the facility on
3/7/24. All staff reported they have not seen Youth B demonstrate
or express any fear towards any staff. They all reported he has
strong preferences for which staff he likes and dislikes. They all
reported they have never seen any staff blatantly or intentionally
ignore or disregard Youth B’s BSP.
Staff 13 was interviewed via phone on 3/14/24. Staff 13
reported there are staff Youth B does not like, including her, but
she has never seen Youth B demonstrate or express any fear
towards any staff. Staff 13 reported when Youth B doesn’t like
staff, he demonstrates it by groaning, swatting at them,
10

whining/crying, throwing things at them, and/or trying to hit them.
Staff 13 reported there are some days the same staff he disliked
the day before, he will suddenly respond well to, wave and say hi.
Staff 13 reported she has never seen or heard of any staff
intentionally ignoring Youth B’s BSP. Staff 13 reported there are
various staff who might not go through the planned ignoring
process they’re supposed to, but this is not a pattern for any
specific staff. Staff 13 reported Youth B loves attention, so even
the littlest bit of attention by a staff might unintentionally go against
his BSP at some point, but it’s typically an honest mistake.
Staff 14 was interviewed face to face at another facility on
3/15/24. Staff 14 reported she has seen Youth B react very poorly
to Staff 15 and it is clear he doesn’t like her. Staff 14 could not
determine if it would be considered fear or not. Staff 14 reported
anytime Staff 15 is around Youth B, Youth B is crying, throwing
things at her, or aggressing towards her. Staff 14 reported he is
preferential with staff, but those preferences may change day-to-
day. Staff 14 reported she has never seen Youth B’s preference
towards Staff 15 change.
Youth B was unable to be interviewed because he is non-
verbal.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Great Lakes Center for Autism Treatment and Researched
Licensed Settings Policy Regarding Discipline and
Behavior Management states each youth will have a
behavior treatment plan developed that addresses how
staff are to respond to that individual’s target behavior.
When a youth demonstrates a behavior not accounted for
in the plan, or when the prescribed response cannot be
implemented, staff will be required to use their discretion as
to how to respond to the behavior. The policy outlines
appropriate responses that could be used in these
situations.
• Youth B’s Behavior Treatment Plan (a.k.a. BSP) (updated
3/29/23) outlines Youth B’s history, diagnoses,
medications, assessed behaviors, target behaviors,
monitored behaviors, proactive strategies, reactive
strategies, restrictive activities, and data/documentation
required.
HR Files were reviewed for the staff who were indicated to have
struggled in their relationship with Youth B.
11

• Staff 4 has four disciplinary actions in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 4 received training on
the discipline/behavior management policy and Youth B’s
BSP on 4/27/22.
• Staff 5 does not have any disciplinary actions in his
employee file. Staff 5 received training on the
discipline/behavior management policy and Youth B’s BSP
during new hire orientation in October 2021.
• Staff 6 has five disciplinary actions in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 6 received training on
the discipline/behavior management policy and Youth B’s
BSP during new hire orientation in February 2023.
• Staff 9 has one disciplinary action in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 9 received training on
the discipline/behavior management policy and Youth B’s
BSP during new hire orientation in August 2023.
• Staff 13 does not have any disciplinary actions in her
employee file. Staff 13 received training on the
discipline/behavior management policy and Youth B’s BSP
during new hire orientation in February 2023.
• Staff 15 does not have any disciplinary actions in her
employee file. Staff 15 received training on the
discipline/behavior management policy and Youth B’s BSP
during new hire orientation in February 2023.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. All employees interviewed reported
any concerns about Youth B demonstrating or expressing fear
towards any staff. No employees interviewed reported there are
any staff who intentionally or blatantly ignore Youth B’s BSP.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
April 18, 2024
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 19, 2024
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
13
